channel.title: Plunkett
channel.description: If a blogger blogs in the woods, does anyone read it?

item.title: Island Hopping
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Well I've been putting this off for quite some time. What I should have done is keep post small excerpts from my trip. Instead all I'm left to do is to either post some form of summary or just pretend like I was never there. Purely for my own benefit, as some form of postXXX strategy, I will try to write everything down here. Already it's hard to recall anything concrete from the trip. It's only been about two weeks... Before I even managed to leave the ground Solomon time struck. When I arrived at the Brisbane International Airport in the morning, bags packed and ready to fly, I found that the flight had been delayed until later that afternoon. After a few months of sitting around doing nothing, I had another few hours to wait. Well the first thing you notice when you get off the plane is the humidity. I arrived quite late dressed in a shorts and t-shirt, around 9 o'clock, and it was still extremely warm. From that moment until I stepped foot back on Australian soil I was wanting for warm clothes. I'll admit that early in the morning, and on some cool evenings, you might feel the urge to put on a sweater or jeans. The rest of the time you are most likely sweating. Of course you eventually acclimatise. Getting around Honiara can be interesting depending on where you live. The point to make is that there is no formal system of addresses. Streets quite often don't have names, and houses most certainly don't have numbers. Giving directions to the taxi drivers can be as simple as naming the owner of the house, or as in-depth as providing directions based on landmarks, depending on the driver. If you live or work near the main road, which is the only one and runs in a straight line from one end of Honiara to the other, catching a bus is the preferred means of transport. When I say "bus" I'm not strictly talking about buses as we know them, instead just imagine a white van with a destination sign stuck to the front windscreen and crammed with passengers. Buses are quite frequent and if you don't need to wait long at a bus stop to catch one. When you went to get off again, you either need to raise your eyebrows to the money collector (a common form of communication - usually meaning some form of affirmation) or whistle between your teeth. Depending on where you sit on the bus you might need to squeeze past a few people to get off. Driving in Honiara can be considered an experience in off-road . Only a few of the major roads are paved with concrete, and all of them have an array of potholes scattered in places. After a few weeks driving, you because familiar with the various potholes and learn when to dodge the worst ones, which can be invaluable at night time. Grey car Language Food Trash Frisby On my third day in the Solomons Wren had arranged for me and Tom, a friend of a friend, to the Mataniko falls. When I first met Tom he had two fully blown inner tubes under his arms. As it turns out once you make it to the falls you can then leisurely float back down the river. While I felt pretty stupid being a whiteman lugging around a tyre, once you make it to the top and start floating back it is well worth it. http://exploringsolomons.wikispaces.com/honiara_bushwalks#tochoniara_bushwalks1 http://exploringsolomons.wikispaces.com/mataniko_pics After that Wren had also organised a scuba diving . I am now a fully qualified PADI Open Water diver. Basically this means I can dive up to 18 metres. After my touristy first week Wren got the whip cracking and started me working at Solomon Islands Development Trust (SIDT). This primarily involved setting up a central file server. Initially all their work files were scattered amongst the various machines on various user profiles. When someone needed a particular file to work on they would require the use of that machine to retrieve it. Obviously not the most ideal situation. The trickiest part for me working at SIDT was keeping in mind that the local IT support was rudimentary and expensive, and try to avoid implementing anything that would then One the last weekend Wren, Kweku and I travelled to Savo, the dormant volcanic island just off the west tip of Guadalcanal. This was meant to be my first and last time to experience the authentic village life of the Solomon Islands. (XXX hustlebustle). In the morning what I found most entertaining was breakfast, which was simply white bread. No butter. No spreads. White bread. Yummy! In the morning we trekked up a dry river bed formed by lava which eventually led to a warm (and eventually boiling) spring, which in turn led to the centre of the volcano. We then climbed out top and down the side. At the highest peak we were walked along a very soft ridge not much wider than a person and which had collapsed at various points. There were lots of nasty looking spiders as well, although interestingly I believe that none of their spiders or snakes are poisonous, unlike everything bloody one in Australia. Not much to add, and I'll let the pictures do the talking. http://picasaweb.google.com/charleso/Savo

item.title: If a blogger blogs in the woods does anyone read it?
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Putting my integrity aside, I have decided to start up a blog. Why, you might ask, when already the world has too many bloggers littering the web with their mindless chatter (no offence intended)? I guess one of the reasons is that I want to keep friends and family back home informed of whatever it is I'm up to. I have a unexplainable dislike for the bulk emails people send around when they go travelling. I'm absolutely terrible at correspondence (just ask anyone) but I'm hoping that being able to write little snippets of trivia will be more appealing than having to cram everything into one long email. Do I have anything really interesting and profound to say? Nup. Will anyone read it? Unlikely. None the less I am going to blog away my thoughts, if and when I have any, in the vague hope that someone might actually read them.

item.title: RSS
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: For those of you who aren't complete nerds I thought I would mention a little something called RSS. One problem with a website blog is that you don't know when a new post is made (assuming you care in the first place). With certain programs you can subscribe to RSS feeds, which will then notify you when something new is added. Examples of RSS programs are Feed Reader, Sharp Reader or even just Firefox/Opera/IE7. There are heaps! Whenever you see the little icon at the top right of your browser (assuming you don't still use IE 6 - if you do, download Firefox or Opera now, do not pass go, do not collection 200 dollars) you know that this particular page has an associated RSS feed. Clicking this icon will allow you to copy and paste the link address into your RSS reader/program. For example mine is http://charleso.wordpress.com/feed/. To make things more complicated, but hopefully better, you might have lots of these feeds and you read them from more than one place (ie work and home). You might also get sick of having to add new exciting feeds into each program, and then have to get notified multiple times about the same post (this might not make sense until you actually try it). To help with this you can use an online RSS reader, such as Bloglines or Google Reader (I use the latter) which you can access from anywhere and see what's new. Finally you can these use one of the above programs to subscribe to the single RSS feed of your chosen online reader, which then informs you about all your feeds in one go. Of course I mention all this purely in the vain hope that someone actually might want to read this blog...

item.title: Tahune to you too
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Sam, Jem and I decided to make an afternoon road trip to Tahune air walk; to be one with nature, breathe in the fresh forest air, and to of course make fun of the latin names of various plant life. More happy snaps can be found here.

item.title: Oh Brisbane, Where Art Thou?
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: This is my first post from the sunny state of Brisbane, or BrisVegas as some people like to call it. Since then I've been pottering around and getting my feet grounded in this new and exciting place (ie I'm not bored... yet). I'm still in this daze like state that some of you may have noticed back in Hobart. In this state I am immune and oblivious to the concerns of "real life", such as getting a job or what I'm actually going to do with myself. I suppose the sooner I snap out of this state the better, but for now I'm enjoying feeling like I am on an extended holiday of sorts. No pressure. No responsibilities. No wucking furries. Here are some initial photos of my arrival in Brisbane, and in particular Dad's house. Dad picking me up from the airport. Stuck in traffic... already! The tree in front of Dad's house. My room on arrival. The above photos can also be found here. Here is a Google Maps picture of where Dad lives. If you click on the image below you will get a nice big arrow pointing to the exact house. Zooming out slightly you will see the Gaythorne train station that is only two blocks away. Very convenient. I'm about to head off to Pomona for the weekend. Pomona is a lovely little town about an hour and a halfs drive North of Brisbane. Hopefully if the weather is nice we will be able to head east to Noosa, or somewhere nearby, for a swim.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
charles o'farrell, this site is much too arty and well designed. i demand you take it down and replace with something much less nice.
good day, good sir.
Absolutely do not take any notice - it's great! Well done! Will explore RSS again (have some knowledge from past work experiences) - after I conquer Skype (again!)

item.title: Is that mushroom growing in your garden, or are you just happy to see me?
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Well I haven't got anything particularly exciting to report about my weekend. I spent most of the time painting the inside of an outdoor garage. Fun. I would like to share the following plant which we found in the garden. I don't think I need to say any more about this... Also, here a flattering shot (love that hair) of me playing guitar after just waking up.

item.title: Blogging, two units
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded:
It's funny how even though I don't currently have a job, and thus I am free to go insane due to boredom, I still manage to fill up my entire day with something. I feel a bit like Hugh Grant in About a boy where he describes breaking his day up into a number of units. In my case:
I find the key is to think of the day in units of time no more than 30 minutes. Riding my bike, three units. Checking my email, two units. Web-based research, two units. Writing a blog entry, two units. It's amazing how the day fills up, and I often wonder, to be absolutely honest, if I'd ever have time for a job; how do people cram them in?
In all seriousness I have been busy with organising a passport, job hunting and implementing my 1 step fitness plan: How not to become a fat bastard by bike riding every day. However, this can only last so long and I'll have make a concrete decision about getting a job or travelling fairly soon. At this point I've pretty much got my sights set on travelling, it's only a matter of where now. Comments about recommended destination spots are welcome.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Chuck, you can always come and visit me! I can provide crap american beer and chocolate at no charge! :-)

item.title: Beer is here
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded:
Just in case any of you were worried that, being in Queensland, I would have to be drinking the piss they call beer: XXXX. And I quote:
It's called XXXX 'cause you can't put SHIT on a beer label
Not to fear. There is a local beer Eumundi Premium Lager which is an excellent drop. Cheers!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
You say that, but its not cascade.
Cheers
Jay

Very true. I will miss cheap quality Tasmanian beer. :-(
It's also not free on Friday's either. Doh!

item.title: Green Thumb
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Yesterday, rather than mope around the house, I headed off to Northy Street City Farm. Northy Street is a place where all different types of people, for various reasons, work to maintain a garden that can in turn be used by the community. On every Sunday a market is held there where the grown produce, such as fresh vegetables and fruit, are sold to the general public. On my first day there I was assigned to a spindly looking lady Meg, who was great fun to work with. Meg helps out at Northy Street three times a week as part of a horticultural course that she is undertaking there. I initially assisted in shifting and laying down mulch over an area which was previously maintained by chickens. The aim of which is to kill off the remainder of the weeds that grow there before starting a new garden, of which the exact species and type of plants are yet to be decided. After morning tea a couple of kids on community service, who can't have been older than 15, took over from me. I did wonder at the time what exactly they had done to end up there. Meg didn't know either, but apparently the hard nuts are assigned to the gardens on Friday. My next chore was to plant baby Bok Choy plants in one of their numerous vegetable patches. Time flies when you're sweating your arse off in the hot Queensland sun, and before I knew it was lunchtime. Not surprisingly lunch is prepared by other volunteers and made with materials from the garden. Suffice it to say it was a very green looking lunch, but very tasty and I said so to Meg. She replied that after 4 days of Arrowroot all she wanted was a Mars bar. After lunch I helped cultivate some Rosemary shoots in the nursery. I just wanted to say I always found the idea of sticking a twig in the ground, pouring some water on it, and expecting it to grow just slightly odd/amazing/far-fetched. However, I will leave the growing and nurturing of plants to the experts. This may sound strange or even unbelievable to some of you that haven't seen me take my eyes off a computer screen in quite some time. I don't blame you really. However, it was so refreshing to be outside on the nice day doing something physical for a change. It is a pity that programming is not more an outdoorsy activity. It was also good to meet new people, as I am still a stranger in a strange land at this point, not knowing a great deal of people. I have arranged to go back next Tuesday, which I am looking forward to.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Next thing you know, they'll have you on the 'real greens' chucko. look out!
bloody hippies.
did any of the 'hard nuts' try to crush your fingers in the trouser press?

Ah - am on gardening duty at Wentworth St myself over Easter - putting in a watering system - drip feed of course so I don't over-water! My new herb garden is doing well - hope your 'twigs' are too! Glad you enjoyed it - it is a very relaxing (not physically, but mentally) activity. Continue to have fun Xxxxxx M

item.title: Old(er) Man
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Turned 25 today. Big whoop.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Happy birthday (of course :). Was it...?
Happy birthday you old fart

item.title: Crikey!
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: The other week Rose (Libby's (Dad's girlfriend) daughter), Robbie (Rose's Scottish boyfriend) and I visited the illustrious Australian Zoo for a bit of touristy action. It was surprisingly good, and I would recommend it to anyone with a spare $45 bucks lying around (No, I don't think it was worth that much). One attraction we saw was the Bird, Snake and Croc show which, while being worth seeing, had some very un-entertaining hosts who tried just a little too hard to be funny. The typical "Who is excited to be here?!?" and "Where is every from?" audience participation questions got tired petty quickly. Just shut up and bring out the Crocs! As a tourist I took some obligatory animal shots. It's a hard life being a Koala (not too dissimilar from being an unemployed bum I have to say). What are you laughing at? Robbie has kept the feeling. The rest of my tourist shots can be found here.

item.title: Boring Point
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Following our trip to the Australian Zoo, Rose, Robbie and I went camping at Boreen Point just for the hell-of-it. Despite my title of this post, it was very relaxing, and we spent the time playing a touch of beach Cricket and Petanque. The camping ground is right next to a lake, which is not very deep and can apparently be walked across. We went swimming and I put this theory to the test. After about five minutes of walking I couldn't be bothered any longer and turned back. Robbie taking a photo of the tree. My own attempt at an artistic shot of the tree. Rose and Robbie admiring the tree photo. This was the Kookabura that tried to eat our breakfast. Be warned these guys are laughing at you and not with you. Unlike other scavengers they will quite happily swoop down and grab food from you as it makes its way from your plate to your mouth. While I don't have any photos of the event, Robbie and I went canoeing on the lake and both ended up falling in getting soaking wet. Fortunately we could both just stand up, empty the canoe and get back in. The rest of the photos can be found here.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Did you love that tree or what???

item.title: My voice is my passport
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Finally got my passport in the mail! Now I just have to decide where the hell I want to go. (I'll try to upload a shot later of my photo so everyone can have a laugh at it)

item.title: Are you lookin' at me?
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: I've finally got around to scanning in my passport photo. If anyone is wondering why I look so serious it's because you're not allowed to smile for the photo. I was surprised about how strict they are about the dimensions as well. They had to retake my photo twice as my head was slightly too far to the right.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Too far to the right, or just to big??????
:)

item.title: Happy Easter
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: It's a bit late now, but here are some of photos I took during Easter, which I spent up at Pomona. These photos are all taken at Noosa. I hope everyone had as much of a relaxing and pleasant weekend as I did. The rest can be found here.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Oh Noosa, gay capital of Australia.

item.title: Aye Aye Captain
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Last week on Wednesday I spent the day completing a Queensland Recreational marine driver licence. This basically means I can take out Dad's Tinny for a spin without his supervision. In all honesty I'm not likely to do that anytime soon, but it's good knowing that I could. If I wanted to. Which I don't particularly. If you could all just call me Captain O'Farrell from now on that'd be great...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Master Bater?
:)

Oh Captain, my Captain.
Please take me for a spin :)
Salutations, Captain O'Farrell! Congrats

item.title: Pants always beats No Pants
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded:
I went to the doctor today to get a Scuba diving certificate in preparation for possible traveling. The doctor was an old, bearded fellow who didn't smile at all and whose first words to me were Take all your clothes off except your underwear. Now I haven't been to the doctor many times in my life, and this is the first that I've had to remove my pants. I was instantly reminded of the Jerry Seinfeld joke about the very same thing. I wasn't laughing though. Now I'm not one to argue when me being semi-naked will ensure an accurate diagnosis but when I'm walking across the room on my heals or standing with my feet in a straight line and eyes closed I do wonder if the lack of clothing is entirely necessary. Anyway. Apparently I'm fit enough to dive, which is a relief... I think. As Jerry says on Scuba diving:
A great activity where your main goal is to... not die. It's really all I was thinking about the entire day. Don't die, don't die, don't die... There's a fish. There's a rock. Who cares? Don't die...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
"Waterproof watch, that's important: 'Gee I'm completely out of oxygen and look at the time. Now I'm dead AND I'm late'"
At least you don't need to wear a helmet like in skydiving...

pants always beat no pants.
unless you are behind a building at the tasmanian uni on a cold winter night and are quite pissed.
thats right i will never let this one die.
Miss you matey!

item.title: Brisbane River
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Dad and I spent a pleasant morning on Anzac Day cruising up the Brisbane river. Prime Real E$tate. These are just a couple of the smaller apartment blocks along the river. Brisbane City from the river. A bridge. Nuff said. Customs House. Me + City. Dad works top floor at the building in the middle. The Burbs. Only 10 minutes boat ride from the city. Location location. A house bridge. One of the really nice things about Brisbane public transport. Where's Charlie?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Chuck.... you've got something on your face... just around your lips.
(just thought I'd tell you before anyone else did)
Its the wild man from borneo in that photo, chuck where are you????
thats a beard!

arrrrrrrgh chuck me heartie You are becoming a real sea dog now hey? Got abit of that facial hair to go with your sea legs. All these land lubbers in Hobart town don't know what it's all about. Shiver me timbers, you can be my first mate on the Captain Stabbin adventures!

item.title: Waterproof Phone
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded: Over the weekend I decided it would be a good idea to drop my phone in the Noosa River. After taking it apart, leaving it out to dry (the oven helped) and putting it back together, this morning it has made a miraculous recovery. Of course the camera now no longer works, the shiny metal thingy around the keypad doesn't stick to the main case (why is it there in the first place?) and the 1 4 7 and * keys function intermittently.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Oops, that's not good. Interesting that how an entire column of keys are affected.....
Bad news indeed

You didn't do it right, i told you how to do it.
Well done for trying.

item.title: Solo Man
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded:
As many of you probably already know, I have been planning on travelling to the Solomon Islands for the past few weeks. This is a post to let everyone know that my flight is booked and I'm heading off for a month... tomorrow!

Why the Solomons? The idea originally came last Christmas when we were discussing possible travel destinations. Wren suggested I should think about the Solomons. Wren, who is Libby's daughter, has been working for an NGO over in the Solomons for the past year or so. She mentioned that they were in desperate need of someone with computer skills. While at first I thought that the Solomon Islands wasn't really what I had in mind when I considered "travel", over the next couple of weeks the idea slowly took shape in my mind. One of the good things about this idea was that I would be travelling with a purpose, which seems like an important thing to do, rather than wandering aimlessly around taking pictures. The other good thing I suppose is that it isn't very far away, only a 3-hour flight - the same time taken to fly from Hobart to Brisbane direct. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, I would experience a culture and lifestyle on the opposite end of the spectrum to ours. Quitting my job and moving to Brisbane this year has been, in part, about starting something new and different and in this regard I couldn't really ask for anything quite so far removed from my old life than the Solomon Islands. I should add that I haven't really got a concrete plan for what I will do once I arrive. At some point I will need to set up a centralised server for storing various forms of data, like email, something which is considered fairly basic and fundamental by our standards (not that I have any real idea what I'm doing). My previous post about getting a Scuba Diving certificate might also have more context now, as the Solomons is reputed to be one of the best diving sites in the world. Aside from that I hope to take it easy and immerse myself as much as I can in their culture and way of life. I feel at this point in time a need to reflect on (read: crap on about) my time here in Brisbane. It has been almost two whole months since I left Hobart. I can't believe it has been that long. Time flies when you're sitting around on your arse doing nothing. Where has all that time gone? What have I been doing? Not much... (except perhaps growing a controversial beard) To be honest while I had planned to devote some time to doing nothing, I had hoped that by this time I would been in the Solomons, or at least overseas somewhere. I was in fact just starting to plan my trip way back in early April when an Earthquake struck (they don't give them names do they?), causing a Tsunami that swept across parts of the Solomons. Wren found herself tangled up in helping with the disaster recovery, and it's only very recently that things over there have settled back to normal. At that point I perhaps should have reconsidered my destination, but I had made up my mind, and the stubborn part of me didn't really want to have to rethink it all. Instead I sat around some more until the time was right. The question a few people have already put to me is: What will I do when I get back? Jeez, wait until I get back at least. The short answer is unfortunately: I don't know! A part of me wants to stop all this nonsense and get back to a stable nine to five job, buy a house, have kids etc. I haven't necessarily got a problem with all of that. I like what I do, and I hope I never get bored of programming. I also love Brisbane and this never-ending blue sky (although a little rain right about now would be really helpful). I just think there might be more that just working to live and living to work. I know these are not new or unique questions for someone to ask (or whine to their blog about) but I guess I feel like I can do something about it now while I still have this freedom. One thing I learnt from my sitting around is that nothing happens and nothing really changes (this will almost certainly receive cries of "Thank you Captain Obvious"). I had a fantasy that in having so much time to myself that I would reach a Zen like state of being. That I would find my true self and be comfortable in who I am and my role to play in this whole shemozzle. That of course hasn't really happened (surprise, surprise). I did get to watch the entire first season of West Wing in about two days (great show by the way), but there wasn't really any of the Zen action I was hoping for. I'd like to be doing something with my life. Meeting new people. Possibly travelling the globe. Something. I'm not just sure what that something is yet. To finish up this already overly-long post I have a quote from a book I just finished called Solomon Time (doing a bit of research before I go) which is true story about Will Randall, a teacher in England, who finds himself by chance in the Solomon Islands. As Wren has warned me multiple times - the Solomons have a completely different perspective of time and that I shouldn't have high expectations for completing everything right away or even at all. For those of you who know what I'm like - trying to finish everything now, this very instant - you might find it amusing to see what kind of a place I've chosen to visit. It will be interesting to see how I manage in this environment (I'd like to think I'll be just fine).
Solomon Time, Solomon Time - how it was to dominate future events I then had no idea. It is liquid, a fluid that cannot be contained, that has no master, that sloshes backwards and forwards and even from side to side. It has no symmetry or order. Solomon Time plays nobody's rules, yet it loosely dictates that something may happen a little late or perhaps a little early or days late or even days early; it may have happened already or it may never happen at all. Schedules and timetables become irrelevancies, arrangements, meetings, deadlines inconsequential. Solomon Time trickles through every stream in every forest and pumps through the veins of every man or woman born of Solomon. Clocks stop ticking; wristwatches become mere ornaments. Time is governed by the sun and the moon, by light and dark. Months slip by indistinguishable one from the next, December as hot as May, November as wet as June. Daily routine, apart from the the two bookends of morning and evening prayer, is as higgledgy-piggledgy as a child's toy box. Mealtimes become movable feasts. Work, rest and play are as confused as three scoops of ice cream melted in the tropical sun. Of course, days, weeks, years, slip by as they do in every other corner of the world but the islands pay scant attention to the upturned hourglass. Intent on living, they have no time for Time. Solomon Time can be magical; it can blur, twist, distort; it can transport you into an almost ethereal state of blissful calm and serenity - but then sometimes it can just be bloody irritating.
Finally I'd like to thank everyone who has made comments on my previous posts. I'm either too slack or stuck for words to reply but I do very much appreciate it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: can't get Zen? try http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105287/ - Sex and Zen!

Live the dream chuck.
Live the Dream

It is a well known fact that the Solomon natives can smell a under-grown beard from 10 miles away. I'd be careful if I was you - shave it off or be prepared to defend yourself!
Have fun mate :)

item.title: First Day
item.dc:creator: charleso
item.content:encoded:
I know it's been a while since my last post. I'm currently in the process of writing up a post about my time in the Solomon Islands, but I've been very slack. What I didn't want to wait for was to write down my first impressions of my new job. Today was my first day with Mincom, a large international software company, based in Brisbane. From their website:
Mincom is a leading global software solutions and services provider to asset-intensive industries For more than 25 years, Mincom has been providing world-class enterprise resource planning and asset management software solutions to organizations that manage and operate complex capital infrastructure. Mincom delivers total industry solution sets that address the unique business processes and needs of asset-intensive organizations in mining, utilities, transportation, defense and government. Our complementary cross-industry solutions and services support a broad range of industries and include B2B integration, electronic cataloging, and IT outsourcing.
What does that mean? To be honest I'm not sure. Who actually reads that crap on the front pages of company websites? What does that mean for me? It's something to do, something that pays the bills. A way to meet new people. Disclamer: When I say "people", what I meant to say was geeky men, much like myself. My first day was fairly typical for first days. You turn up at the front desk bright and early in the morning and people who have lots of important things to do have to somehow find you something productive to do until you magically learn enough to be useful. For most of the morning I sat around, reading technical documentation, waiting for their IT department to deliver my new computer. For me the big shock is working for a company that has their own building (and swimming pool). I'm used to working for an company that only had a few cubicles to their name (and maybe a pool table). I also got a cool photo ID badge which made me feel special - although I'm sure the novelty will wear off shortly. To be honest, I'm pretty excited about working at Mincom. I know I crapped on about Zen and all that, but it's nice to be doing something productive again. PS. Thomas told me on the phone to write that he is way cool.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am way cool. All others are shims.

Jesus walked on water. He was way cool. He made wine out of water. How cool is that? Jesus was way cool.
Thomas is not cool - he is a shim.
I am a shim!!!!
Keep that Shim talk up and you will be getting visits from Adam
